nodes.full_title: A Tool for Improving Privacy through Enterprise Risk Management
nodes.purpose: Enable better privacy engineering practices that support privacy by design concepts
nodes.name: NIST Privacy Framework 1.0
Workforce
nodes.definition: Personnel, including employees and contractors, who have assigned roles and responsibilities.

nodes.name: Tier
nodes.definition: A characterization of the rigor of an organization’s privacy risk management practices and the extent to which that risk management is integrated into the organization’s overall risk management practices.

nodes.name: System
nodes.definition: A discrete set of information resources organized for the collection, processing, maintenance, use, sharing, dissemination, or disposition of information.

nodes.name: Subcategory
nodes.definition: The subdivision of a Category into specific outcomes of technical and/or management activities. Examples include: Data processing is mapped; and Decentralized data processing is used.

nodes.name: Role
nodes.definition: A set of responsibilities and privileges defined for a user or group of users.

nodes.name: Risk Management
nodes.definition: The process of managing risks to organizational operations (including mission, functions, image, reputation), organizational assets, individuals, other organizations, and the Nation, resulting from the operation of an information system, and includes: (i) the conduct of a risk assessment; (ii) the implementation of a risk mitigation strategy; and (iii) employment of techniques and procedures for the continuous monitoring of the security state of the information system.

nodes.name: Risk
nodes.definition: A measure of the extent to which an entity is threatened by a potential circumstance or event, and typically a function of: (i) the adverse impacts that would arise if the circumstance or event occurs; and (ii) the likelihood of occurrence.

nodes.name: Provenance
nodes.definition: The chronology of the origin, development, ownership, location, and changes to a system or system component and associated data.

nodes.name: Protective Technology
nodes.definition: Communications, physical, and computer security technical solutions employed to protect assets and data.

nodes.name: Profile
nodes.definition: A selection of the specific Functions, Categories, and Subcategories from the Core that the organization has prioritized to help it manage privacy risk.

nodes.name: Problematic Data Action
nodes.definition: A data action that could cause an adverse effect for an individual.

nodes.name: Privacy Risk Assessment
nodes.definition: A process for identifying and evaluating privacy risks.

nodes.name: Privacy Risk
nodes.definition: The potential for problems resulting from data processing that individuals could experience.

nodes.name: Privacy Incident
nodes.definition: A privacy event that results in a problem for an individual.

nodes.name: Privacy Event
nodes.definition: The occurrence of a problematic data action.

nodes.name: Inventory
nodes.definition: A list of the physical and/or logical assets within an organization.

nodes.name: Individual
nodes.definition: A natural person.

nodes.name: Incident
nodes.definition: An occurrence that actually or potentially jeopardizes the confidentiality, integrity, or availability of an information system or the information the system processes, stores, or transmits or that constitutes a violation or imminent threat of violation of security policies, security procedures, or acceptable use policies.

nodes.name: Function
nodes.definition: The highest level of organization in the Core. Functions provide a high-level, strategic view of the lifecycle of an organization’s management of privacy risk. The Functions are Identify-P, Govern-P, Control-P, Communicate-P, and Protect-P.

nodes.name: Framework
nodes.definition: The NIST Privacy Framework: A Tool for Improving Privacy through Enterprise Risk Management.

nodes.name: Event
nodes.definition: An observable occurrence in a system or network.

nodes.name: Ecosystem
nodes.definition: See Data Processing Ecosystem.

nodes.name: Disassociated Processing
nodes.definition: Processing data without associating it with individuals or devices.

nodes.name: De-identification
nodes.definition: The process of removing identifying information from data.

nodes.name: Data Processing
nodes.definition: The collective set of data actions.

nodes.name: Data Element
nodes.definition: The smallest logical unit of data.

nodes.name: Data Action
nodes.definition: A system’s internal operation involving data (e.g., collection, retention, logging, generation, transformation, use, disclosure, sharing, transmission, and disposal).

nodes.name: Data
nodes.definition: A representation of information, knowledge, facts, concepts, or instructions.

nodes.name: Cybersecurity
nodes.definition: The process of protecting information by preventing, detecting, and responding to attacks.

nodes.name: Core
nodes.definition: A set of privacy activities, desired outcomes, and applicable references that are common across critical infrastructure sectors, organizations, and systems.

nodes.name: Confidentiality
nodes.definition: Preserving authorized restrictions on information access and disclosure, including means for protecting personal privacy and proprietary information.

nodes.name: Component
nodes.definition: See System Component.

nodes.name: Communications and Control Networks
nodes.definition: Networks that allow communication between elements of a control system or between control systems and other systems.

nodes.name: Category
nodes.definition: The subdivision of a Function into groups of privacy outcomes, closely tied to programmatic needs and particular activities. Examples include Inventory and Mapping, Governance Policies, Processes, and Procedures, and Data Processing Management.

nodes.name: Capability
nodes.definition: A combination of mutually reinforcing controls, processes, and knowledge that enable the organization to manage risk.

nodes.name: Business Environment
nodes.definition: The mission, objectives, stakeholders, and activities of the organization.

nodes.name: Availability
nodes.definition: Ensuring timely and reliable access to and use of information.

nodes.name: Asset
nodes.definition: Data, personnel, devices, systems, and facilities that enable the organization to achieve business purposes.

nodes.name: Agency
nodes.definition: See United States Government Federal Agency.

nodes.name: Adaptive
nodes.description: • Privacy Risk Management Process – The organization adapts its privacy practices based on lessons learned from privacy events, and identification of new privacy risks. Through a process of continuous improvement incorporating advanced privacy technologies and practices, the organization actively adapts to a changing policy and technology landscape and responds in a timely and effective manner to evolving privacy risks. • Integrated Privacy Risk Management Program – There is an organization-wide approach to managing privacy risk that uses risk-informed policies, processes, and procedures to address problematic data actions. The relationship between privacy risk and organizational objectives is clearly understood and considered when making decisions. Senior executives monitor privacy risk in the same context as cybersecurity risk, financial risk, and other organizational risks. The organizational budget is based on an understanding of the current and predicted risk environment and risk tolerance. Business units implement executive vision and analyze system-level risks in the context of the organizational risk tolerances. Privacy risk management is part of the organizational culture and evolves from lessons learned and continuous awareness of data processing and resulting privacy risks. The organization can quickly and efficiently account for changes to business/mission objectives in how risk is approached and communicated. • Data Processing Ecosystem Relationships – The organization understands its role(s), dependencies, and dependents in the larger ecosystem and contributes to the community's broader understanding of risks. The organization uses real-time or near-real-time information to understand and consistently act upon privacy ecosystem risks associated with the products and services it provides and it uses. Additionally, it communicates proactively, using formal (e.g., agreements) and informal mechanisms to develop and maintain strong ecosystem relationships. • Workforce – The organization has specialized privacy skillsets throughout the organizational structure; personnel with diverse perspectives contribute to the management of privacy risks. There is regular, up-to-date, specialized privacy training for all personnel. Personnel at all levels understand the organizational privacy values and their role in maintaining them.

nodes.name: Repeatable
nodes.description: • Privacy Risk Management Process – The organization’s risk management practices are formally approved and expressed as policy. Organizational privacy practices are regularly updated based on the application of risk management processes to changes in mission or business objectives and a changing risk, policy, and technology landscape. • Integrated Privacy Risk Management Program – There is an organization-wide approach to manage privacy risk. Risk-informed policies, processes, and procedures are defined, implemented as intended, and reviewed. Consistent methods are in place to respond effectively to changes in risk. The organization consistently and accurately monitors privacy risk. Senior privacy and non-privacy executives communicate regularly regarding privacy risk. Senior executives ensure consideration of privacy through all lines of operation in the organization. • Data Processing Ecosystem Relationships – The organization understands its role(s), dependencies, and dependents in the larger ecosystem and may contribute to the community’s broader understanding of risks. The organization is aware of the privacy ecosystem risks associated with the products and services it provides and it uses. Additionally, it usually acts formally upon those risks, including mechanisms such as written agreements to communicate privacy requirements, governance structures, and policy implementation and monitoring. • Workforce – Dedicated privacy personnel possess the knowledge and skills to perform their appointed roles and responsibilities. There is regular, up-to-date privacy training for all personnel.

nodes.name: Risk Informed
nodes.description: • Privacy Risk Management Process – Risk management practices are approved by management but may not be established as organization-wide policy. Prioritization of privacy activities is directly informed by organizational risk management priorities, privacy risk assessments, or mission or business objectives. • Integrated Privacy Risk Management Program – There is an awareness of privacy risk at the organizational level, but an organization-wide approach to managing privacy risk has not been established. Information about data processing and resulting privacy risks is shared within the organization on an informal basis. Consideration of privacy in organizational objectives and programs may occur at some but not all levels of the organization. Privacy risk assessment occurs, but is not typically repeatable or reoccurring. • Data Processing Ecosystem Relationships – There is some understanding of an organization’s role(s) in the larger ecosystem with respect to other entities (e.g., buyers, suppliers, service providers, business associates, partners). The organization is aware of the privacy ecosystem risks associated with the products and services it provides and uses, but does not act consistently or formally upon those risks. • Workforce – There are personnel with specific privacy responsibilities, but they may have non-privacy responsibilities as well. Privacy training is conducted regularly for privacy personnel, although there is no consistent process for updates on best practices.

nodes.name: Partial
nodes.description: • Privacy Risk Management Process – Organizational privacy risk management practices are not formalized, and risk is managed in an ad hoc and sometimes reactive manner. Prioritization of privacy activities may not be directly informed by organizational risk management priorities, privacy risk assessments, or mission or business objectives. • Integrated Privacy Risk Management Program – There is limited awareness of privacy risk at the organizational level. The organization implements privacy risk management on an irregular, case-by-case basis due to varied experience or information gained from outside sources. The organization may not have processes that enable the sharing of information about data processing and resulting privacy risks within the organization. • Data Processing Ecosystem Relationships – There is limited understanding of an organization’s role(s) in the larger ecosystem with respect to other entities (e.g., buyers, suppliers, service providers, business associates, partners). The organization does not have processes for identifying how privacy risks may proliferate throughout the ecosystem or for communicating privacy risks or requirements to other entities in the ecosystem. • Workforce – Some personnel may have a limited understanding of privacy risks or privacy risk management processes, but have no specific privacy responsibilities. If available, privacy training is ad hoc and the content is not kept current with best practices.

nodes.name: Protect-P
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate data processing safeguards.

nodes.name: Protective Technology
nodes.description: Technical security solutions are managed to ensure the security and resilience of systems/products/services and associated data, consistent with related policies, processes, procedures, and agreements.
Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to ensure resilience requirements are met in normal and adverse situations.
Communications and control networks are protected.
The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities.
Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy.

nodes.name: Maintenance
nodes.description: System maintenance and repairs are performed consistent with policies, processes, and procedures.
Remote maintenance of organizational assets is approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access.
Maintenance and repair of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools.

nodes.name: Data Security
nodes.description: Data are managed consistent with the organization’s risk strategy to protect individuals’ privacy and maintain data confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify hardware integrity.
The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment.
Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity.
Protections against data leaks are implemented.
Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained.
Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition.
Data-in-transit is protected.
Data-at-rest is protected.

nodes.name: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control
nodes.description: Access to data and devices is limited to authorized individuals, processes, and devices, and is managed consistent with the assessed risk of unauthorized access.
Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions.
Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation).
Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties.
Remote access is managed.
Physical access to assets is managed and protected.
Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, processes, and individuals.

nodes.name: Data Protection Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.description: Security and privacy policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used to manage the protection of data and systems.
Vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented.
Voluntary or automated mechanisms for data sharing are used.
Processes for data destruction are maintained and used.
Development and testing environments are separate from the production environment.
System/product/service configuration baselines are created and maintained.
Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy.
Protective technology policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used.
Maintenance policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used.
Data security policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used.
Identity management and access control policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used.

nodes.name: Communicate-P
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations and individuals to have a reliable understanding and engage in a dialogue about how data are processed and associated privacy risks.

nodes.name: Data Processing Awareness
nodes.description: Individuals and organizations have reliable knowledge about data processing practices and associated privacy risks, and effective mechanisms are used and maintained to increase predictability consistent with the organization’s risk strategy to protect individuals’ privacy.
Mechanisms (e.g., correction forms) are used to communicate data corrections to individuals and organizations.
Mechanisms (e.g., account access logs) are used to communicate data access and disclosures to individuals and organizations.
Mechanisms (e.g., feedback surveys, focus groups) are used to receive and respond to feedback from individuals and organizations about data processing and associated privacy risks.
Mechanisms (e.g., privacy settings, preferences) are used to communicate individuals’ data processing preferences and requests.
Mechanisms (e.g., public reports) are used to communicate privacy -related roles and responsibilities in the data processing ecosystem.
Mechanisms (e.g., notices, internal or public reports) are used to communicate how data processing changes as a result of privacy risk management decisions.
Mechanisms (e.g., internal or public reports) are used to communicate data processing provenance, lineage, and/or scope.
Mechanisms (e.g., notices, internal or public reports) are used to communicate data processing purposes, practices, and associated privacy risks.

nodes.name: Communication Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.description: Policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used to increase transparency of the organization’s data processing practices.
Roles and responsibilities (e.g., public relations, human resources) for communicating data processing and associated privacy risks are established and communicated.

Transparency policies, processes, and procedures for data processing (e.g., purpose, scope, roles and responsibilities in the data processing ecosystem, and management commitment) and associated privacy risks are maintained and used.

nodes.name: Control-P
nodes.definition: Develop and implement appropriate activities to enable organizations or individuals to manage data with sufficient granularity to manage privacy risks.

nodes.name: Disassociated Processing
nodes.description: Data processing solutions increase disassociability consistent with the organization’s risk strategy to protect individuals’ privacy and enable implementation of privacy principles (e.g., data minimization).
Data elements are processed to limit the association of organizations with other organizations.
Data elements are processed to limit the association of data elements with organizations.
Data elements are processed to limit the association of individuals and/or devices with other individuals and/or devices.
Data elements are processed to limit the association of data elements with other data elements.
Data elements are processed to limit the association of data elements with individuals and/or devices.

nodes.name: Data Processing Management
nodes.description: Data are managed consistent with the organization’s risk strategy to protect individuals’ privacy, increase manageability, and enable the implementation of privacy principles (e.g., individual participation, data quality, data minimization).
Data elements are processed to limit the identification of individuals.
Data elements are processed to limit the observation and/or linkability of data and/or individuals.
Data elements are processed to limit the granularity of data.
Data elements are processed to limit the sensitivity of data.
Data elements are processed to check for accuracy and quality.
Data elements are transmitted, disclosed, or shared with the requisite organizations and individuals.
Data elements can be accessed for deletion.
Data elements can be accessed for alteration.
Data elements can be accessed for disclosure.
Data elements can be accessed for review.

nodes.name: Data Processing Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.description: Policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used to manage data processing (e.g., purpose, scope, roles and responsibilities in the data processing ecosystem, and management commitment) consistent with the organization’s risk strategy to protect individuals’ privacy.
Processes to assess and manage the privacy risks associated with third parties (e.g., service providers, customers, partners) are maintained and used.
Processes for conducting privacy review of new or changed data actions are maintained and used.
System/product/service design and development (e.g., DevOps, system development life cycle [SDLC]) and data life cycle processes incorporate privacy considerations.

Privacy policies, processes, and procedures are maintained and used to govern data processing (e.g., data generation/collection, use, transmission, disclosure, retention, deletion/destruction) and data provenance.

nodes.name: Govern-P
nodes.definition: Develop and implement the organizational governance structure to enable an ongoing understanding of the organization’s risk management priorities that are informed by privacy risk.

nodes.name: Monitoring and Review
nodes.description: The policies, processes, and procedures for ongoing review of the organization’s privacy posture are understood and inform the management of privacy risk.
Processes are improved based on the results of reviews, audits, or other forms of evaluations.
Audits or other forms of evaluations are conducted.
Policies, processes, and procedures are established to verify that privacy risk responses are implemented and effective.
Rules and agreements for data sharing and retention are reviewed and adjusted.
Organizational privacy priorities, risk tolerances, and assumptions are reviewed and adjusted.
Changes to the privacy risk environment, including legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements, are identified and incorporated into privacy risk management decisions.
Privacy risk is re-evaluated on an ongoing basis as system/product/service capabilities, permissions, and data actions change.

nodes.name: Awareness and Training
nodes.description: The organization’s workforce and third parties engaged in data processing are provided privacy awareness education and are trained to perform their privacy-related duties and responsibilities consistent with related policies, processes, procedures, and agreements and organizational privacy values.
Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities.
Third -party stakeholders (e.g., service providers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities.
Privileged users understand their roles and responsibilities.
All personnel are informed and trained on their roles and responsibilities for privacy -related duties.

nodes.name: Risk Management Strategy
nodes.description: The organization’s priorities, constraints, risk tolerances, and assumptions are established and used to support operational risk decisions.

The organization’s determination of risk tolerance is informed by the role of the organization in the data processing ecosystem and the specific role of the organization in the data processing value chain.
Organizational risk tolerance is determined and clearly expressed.
Risk management processes are established, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders.

nodes.name: Governance Policies, Processes, and Procedures
nodes.description: The policies, processes, and procedures to manage and monitor the organization’s regulatory, legal, risk, environmental, and operational requirements are understood and inform the management of privacy risk.
Governance and risk management policies, processes, and procedures address privacy risks.
Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding privacy are identified and communicated.
Privacy roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with internal and external partners.
Roles and responsibilities for the workforce are established and communicated.
Processes to instill organizational privacy values in the workforce are established and communicated.

Organizational privacy values and policies (e.g., conditions on data processing such as data uses or retention periods , individuals ’ prerogatives with respect to data processing) are established and communicated.

nodes.name: Identify-P
nodes.definition: Develop the organizational understanding to manage privacy risk for individuals arising from data processing.

nodes.name: Data Processing Ecosystem Risk Management
nodes.description: The organization’s priorities, constraints, risk tolerances, and assumptions are established and used to support risk decisions associated with managing privacy risks within the data processing ecosystem.
Data processing ecosystem parties are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual obligations.
Interoperability frameworks or similar multi-party approaches to managing privacy risk in the data processing ecosystem are identified and prioritized.
Data processing ecosystem partners, such as data sources, third parties, and data consumers are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process.

The organization’s role(s) in the data processing ecosystem and its associated supply chain risk management roles and responsibilities are identified, established, managed, assessed, and communicated.
Data processing ecosystem risk management policies, processes, and procedures are identified, established, assessed, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders.

nodes.name: Risk Assessment
nodes.description: The organization understands the privacy risks to individuals and how such privacy risks may create follow-on impacts on organizational operations, including mission, functions, other risk management priorities (e.g., compliance, financial), reputation, workforce, and culture.
Privacy risk responses are identified and prioritized.
Problematic data actions and problems are assessed to determine the likelihood and impact of privacy risk.
Privacy events are analyzed to determine the potential problematic data actions and problems.
Data processing is reviewed to identify privacy events.
Contextual factors related to the systems/products/services (e.g., individuals’ demographics, socio -cultural norms, political and economic conditions) are identified.

nodes.name: Business Environment
nodes.description: The organization’s mission, objectives, stakeholders, and activities are understood and prioritized; this information is used to inform privacy roles, responsibilities, and risk management decisions.
Systems/products/services that support organizational priorities are identified and key requirements are communicated.
Priorities for organizational mission, objectives, and activities are established and communicated.
The organization’s role (s) in the data processing ecosystem are identified and communicated.

nodes.name: Inventory and Mapping
nodes.description: Data processing by systems, products, or services is understood and informs the management of privacy risk.

Data processing is mapped, illustrating the data actions and associated data elements for systems/products/services, including components; roles of the component owners/operators; and interactions of individuals or third parties with the systems/products/services.
The data processing environment is identified (e.g., geographic location, internal, cloud, third parties).
Data elements within the data actions are inventoried.
The purposes for the data actions are inventoried.
Data actions of the systems/products/services are inventoried.
Categories of individuals (e.g., customers, employees or prospective employees, consumers) whose data are being processed are inventoried.

Owners or operators (e.g., the organization or third parties such as service providers, partners, customers, and developers) and their roles with respect to the systems/products/services and components (e.g., internal or external) that process data are inventoried.
Systems/products/services that process data are inventoried.
